Which of the following would have prevented this near miss?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rarely, ibuprofen can cause hemolytic or aplastic anemia. Ibuprofen-induced pancytopenia is extremely rare; a different cause is more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Systemic glucocorticoids (e.g., prednisone) can cause leukocytosis and increased hemoglobin and red blood cell counts, but not pancytopenia. Withholding prednisone and prescribing azathioprine monotherapy would not have prevented the development of pancytopenia, as azathioprine can cause pancytopenia.

C) INCORRECT:

Supplementation with folic acid is indicated for patients receiving drugs that may cause folate deficiency (e.g., methotrexate). This patient is not receiving any drugs that cause folate deficiency, and folate deficiency would cause anemia, not pancytopenia.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's pancytopenia was likely caused by the interaction between azathioprine and allopurinol. Azathioprine is metabolized to 6-mercaptopurine (6-MP), which causes immunosuppression at low dosages and is cytostatic at high dosages. Allopurinol inhibits xanthine oxidase, which is responsible for the degradation of 6-MP. Concomitant administration of a xanthine oxidase inhibitor causes a toxic accumulation of 6-MP resulting in bone marrow suppression. A thorough assessment of potential drug interactions before initiating azathioprine could have prevented the development of pancytopenia in this patient. Coadministration of azathioprine and allopurinol should be avoided. The dose of azathioprine (or any other purine analog) should be reduced if concomitant administration with allopurinol is unavoidable.

Alternatives to azathioprine with less impact on bone marrow, such as cyclosporine, would have been a safer option for this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

A CT scan of the chest is indicated in all patients with myasthenia gravis to assess for a thymoma or thymic hyperplasia. Thymomas are associated with pure red cell aplasia and immunodeficiency, but not pancytopenia.
questions.hint: This patient has pancytopenia.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman presents with persistent and worsening shortness of breath, cough, and wheezing on exertion. She reports that she has had asthma symptoms for years, with seasonal changes in the past 2 to 3 weeks.
She has had allergic and pulmonary symptoms on and off throughout her life, but in the past few years, standard therapies (inhaled fluticasone-salmeterol, albuterol, tiotropium, and montelukast) have not prevented her from requiring intermittent visits to the emergency department (ED) for symptom flares. Treatment in the ED has consisted of nebulizers and short courses of prednisone. The patient has also been treated for thrush in the past 6 months.
Prior evaluations demonstrate positive skin testing against dust mites and an immunoglobulin E level of 508 IU/mL (reference range, 10–179).
Pulmonary function testing reveals a FEV1 of 65% of predicted and an FEV1 /FVC ratio of 60%.
A chest radiograph is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following therapies is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ipratropium nebulizers are not likely to be more effective than inhaled tiotropium in this clinical context.

B) INCORRECT:

Inhaled DNase is effective in treating cystic fibrosis but has not been shown to be effective for asthma.

C) INCORRECT:

Daily prednisone therapy should be avoided given its association with long-term adverse effects.

D) CORRECT:

Omalizumab, a recombinant immunoglobulin G subclass 1 monoclonal anti-immunoglobulin E (IgE) antibody that binds to IgE molecules at the fragment crystallizable region, reduces asthmatic responses to allergen inhalation challenges. Randomized clinical trials have shown that omalizumab can also be effective in patients with elevated total serum IgE levels and positive skin testing to aeroallergens (e.g., dust mites, cockroaches, or pet dander) by lowering the frequency and likelihood of asthma exacerbations. The drug has also been shown to reduce the dose of inhaled glucocorticoid necessary to control symptoms.

Key learning point: An anti-immunoglobulin E antibody that has been shown to be effective for reducing the frequency of exacerbations in patients with uncontrolled asthma is omalizumab.

E) INCORRECT:

Inhaled levalbuterol can be used as a bronchodilator instead of albuterol but has not been shown to be more effective than albuterol.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man with rheumatoid arthritis presents with progressive joint pain and swelling despite treatment with hydroxychloroquine. He was also treated with methotrexate and prednisone in the past, but he tolerated neither medication because of side effects.
He has swelling and tenderness of the proximal interphalangeal joints of his hands, as well as a warm, erythematous left ankle. His lungs are clear, his cardiac examination is normal, and his skin examination is notable only for the findings associated with his joints.
He works as an administrator for an insurance company, and his only travel history was 20 years ago, when he was a Peace Corps member in Southeast Asia. He recently tested negative for HIV infection.
Adalimumab, a tumor necrosis factor inhibitor, has been recommended to help manage his disease.
Which one of the following investigations should be done before this patient initiates adalimumab therapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

There are mixed data on whether TNF inhibitors increase the overall risk of malignancy. Patients receiving TNF inhibitors should undergo age-appropriate cancer screening. The recommended age at which to initiate colorectal cancer screening in average-risk individuals depends on the specific guidelines being followed. Historically, most guidelines have recommended starting screening at age 50, but increasingly, guidelines recommend starting at age 45 because of the rising incidence of colorectal cancer in younger populations.

B) CORRECT:

Blockade of tumor necrosis factor (TNF) is the mechanism of action of various medications (e.g., adalimumab and infliximab) used to treat autoimmune conditions and inflammatory bowel disease. Treatment with TNF inhibitors increases the risk for reactivation of latent tuberculosis infection and viral hepatitis. Before treatment with TNF inhibitors is initiated, the patient should be screened for latent tuberculosis infection (by means of tuberculin skin testing) and for viral hepatitis.

Key learning point: Before starting a tumor necrosis factor inhibitor, patients should be screened for latent tuberculosis infection and viral hepatitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Although active tuberculosis infections can affect the gastrointestinal system, patients with tuberculous enteritis frequently have nonspecific chronic abdominal pain; additional symptoms such as anorexia, fever, night sweats, or diarrhea may also be present. Although a CT scan and colonoscopy can help identify findings consistent with tuberculous enteritis, neither of these tests is indicated in the absence of relevant symptoms or known active tuberculosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Bronchoscopy is reserved for diagnosis if there is concern for active tuberculosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Chest radiography would be indicated if the tuberculin skin testing was positive but should not be used as a screening test. Similarly, bronchoscopy is reserved for diagnosis if there is concern for active tuberculosis.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man who received a liver transplant 5 years ago for alcohol-related cirrhosis reports a 3-day history of tremor. He takes diltiazem and warfarin for recently developed atrial fibrillation; he is also treated with tacrolimus. He reports that he has been alcohol free for more than 10 years.
His heart rate is irregularly irregular at 95 beats per minute, and his blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg. In both hands, he has a fine resting tremor that also affects his arms if outstretched.
A complete blood count is normal, but his serum creatinine level is 1.9 mg/dL (reference range, 0.8–1.3), compared with 0.8 mg/dL two weeks ago. His thyrotropin level is 0.8 μU/mL (0.5–4.7).
What is the most appropriate next step in evaluating this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

If the tacrolimus level is found to be normal, it may be appropriate to perform renal ultrasonography.

B) INCORRECT:

Measuring the free-thyroxine level is not indicated in the evaluation of a patient with tremor if the thyrotropin level is within the normal range.

C) INCORRECT:

Lorazepam is not indicated in the absence of signs of alcohol use disorder or alcohol withdrawal. The drug may treat the tremor but would not correct the underlying problem.

D) INCORRECT:

Increasing the diltiazem dose is unnecessary, given that the patient’s heart rate is normal.

E) CORRECT:

Calcium-channel blockers, such as diltiazem, inhibit cytochrome P-450 enzymes and can cause tacrolimus levels to rise. Common side effects of supratherapeutic tacrolimus levels include headache, hypertension, tremor, and renal insufficiency. Thus, the most appropriate next step in evaluating this patient’s condition is to measure the tacrolimus level and adjust the dose to the appropriate level of immunosuppression.

Key learning point: Adverse effects of supratherapeutic levels of tacrolimus include headache, hypertension, tremor, and renal insufficiency.

questions.text: Treatment of lung cancer with bevacizumab is associated with an increased risk for which one of the following events?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Bevacizumab, a monoclonal antibody against vascular endothelial growth factor, has been associated with significant improvements in overall survival among patients receiving carboplatin and paclitaxel for metastatic non-small-cell lung cancer. However, the drug also has several important side effects, including life-threatening bleeding. In a phase 3 randomized trial, 5 of 417 patients receiving bevacizumab died from pulmonary hemorrhage, and there were also reports of grade 3/4 central nervous system hemorrhage and gastrointestinal bleeding. Other important complications of bevacizumab include malignant hypertension (more common in patients with poorly controlled hypertension at baseline) and nephrotic-range proteinuria. Urine protein should be monitored in patients receiving bevacizumab.

Key learning point: The most common serious adverse event associated with the use of bevacizumab is severe hemorrhage.

B) INCORRECT:

Bevacizumab treatment is not associated with valvular heart disease, sensorineural hearing loss, acute pancreatitis, or nephrolithiasis.

C) INCORRECT:

Bevacizumab treatment is not associated with valvular heart disease, sensorineural hearing loss, acute pancreatitis, or nephrolithiasis.

D) INCORRECT:

Bevacizumab treatment is not associated with valvular heart disease, sensorineural hearing loss, acute pancreatitis, or nephrolithiasis.

E) INCORRECT:

Bevacizumab treatment is not associated with valvular heart disease, sensorineural hearing loss, acute pancreatitis, or nephrolithiasis.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man with a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes, and rheumatoid arthritis presents in the summer with a week of fever, fatigue, and shortness of breath. His medications include methotrexate, infliximab, amlodipine, metformin, and insulin. He had a negative tuberculin skin test before starting therapy with infliximab.
He is a married father of two healthy children and works as a construction manager renovating homes in Indiana. He does not smoke cigarettes and drinks two beers on the weekends. He has no history of travel outside the United States.
His temperature is 39.1°C, and his heart rate is 112 beats per minute. He has diffuse pulmonary crackles, diffuse lymphadenopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly. He has no skin rashes or evidence of active synovitis on examination. A chest radiograph reveals diffuse interstitial infiltrates.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
2600
4500–11,000


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
9.7
13.5–17.5


Platelet count (per mm3)
71,000
150,000–350,000


Total bilirubin (mg/dL)
1.3
0.3–1.0


Direct bilirubin (mg/dL)
0.9
0.1–0.3


Alanine aminotransferase (U/liter)
62
0–35


Aspartate aminotransferase (U/liter)
58
0–35


Alkaline phosphatase (U/liter)
280
30–120


Ferritin (ng/mL)
11,550
30–300


Lactate dehydrogenase (U/liter)
565
100–190


The leukocyte differential shows a neutrophilic predominance. A peripheral-blood smear shows no significant abnormalities.
What is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Miliary tuberculosis does occur in patients taking TNF inhibitors, but this patient had a negative tuberculin skin test before starting infliximab therapy and has no history of tuberculosis exposure, making tuberculosis a much less likely diagnosis than disseminated histoplasmosis.

B) CORRECT:

Tumor necrosis factor (TNF) inhibitors block the granulomatous response to infections, which then predisposes patients to invasive mycobacterial and fungal infections. This patient’s presentation is typical for disseminated histoplasmosis, which has been reported more frequently than other invasive infections in patients taking TNF inhibitors (although disseminated tuberculosis can also occur).

Patients with disseminated histoplasmosis can present with a variety of symptoms depending on the sites of involvement, but fever, fatigue, and weight loss are present in most patients. Respiratory symptoms may be reported, and chest radiographs are frequently abnormal, as in this case. Hepatosplenomegaly and lymphadenopathy may be present on physical examination. On laboratory evaluation, patients typically have high levels of ferritin and lactate dehydrogenase, and they often have a pancytopenia related to bone-marrow involvement. All TNF inhibitors increase the risk of disseminated disease, but the incidence is higher with anti-TNF monoclonal antibodies (e.g., infliximab and adalimumab) than with the soluble-TNF receptors (e.g., etanercept). In the United States, histoplasmosis is widely distributed but is most common in midwestern states in the Ohio and Mississippi River valleys.

Key learning point: Patients who take tumor necrosis factor inhibitors and live in the midwestern United States are at increased risk for infection with disseminated histoplasmosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Sarcoidosis is a possible cause of this patient’s pulmonary findings, and it can also cause fever and elevated aminotransferase levels. However, it does not usually cause pancytopenia. Sarcoidosis and histoplasmosis can be difficult to tell apart, but it is important to rule out histoplasmosis in an at-risk individual before initiating glucocorticoids or other immunosuppressants for presumed sarcoidosis, because these medications can lead to an acute worsening of infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Methotrexate can cause a variety of pulmonary syndromes, including diffuse interstitial disease associated with fever and eosinophilia. It can also cause myelosuppression and liver inflammation. However, it does not cause diffuse lymphadenopathy, and it would be unusual for a patient to present with methotrexate toxicity simultaneously affecting multiple organs (lung, liver, and bone marrow).

E) INCORRECT:

A flare of rheumatoid arthritis is unlikely in this patient given his normal joint examination and would not be expected to cause the constellation of other findings.

questions.text:
A 74-year-old man presents to the emergency department reporting a 2-week history of weakness, dehydration, and profuse diarrhea. He has 10 bowel movements daily that he describes as loose, watery, and nonbloody. He has mild abdominal pain but no fevers, nausea, or vomiting. His medical history is significant for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, hypertension, gout, and recently diagnosed metastatic, unresectable melanoma that has been treated with ipilimumab (a cytotoxic T-lymphocyte antigen-4 inhibitor) for the past 7 weeks. He reports no recent sick contacts, no travel abroad, and no antibiotic exposure. He has not experienced any other new symptoms.
He has a temperature of 36.8°C, a heart rate of 110 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 102/55 mm Hg, and an oxygen saturation of 97% while breathing ambient air. Physical examination reveals dry mucous membranes and poor skin turgor. Cardiac and lung examinations are within normal limits. Abdominal examination reveals diffuse mild tenderness, with no guarding or rigidity.
A complete blood count and liver function tests are within normal limits. Other laboratory results are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Sodium (mEq/liter)
129
136–145


Potassium (mEq/liter)
3.4
3.5–5.0


Chloride (mEq/liter)
90
98–106


Bicarbonate (mEq/liter)
19
21–30


Blood urea nitrogen (mg/dL)
23
10–20


Creatinine (mg/dL)
2.4 (baseline, 1.2)
0.8–1.3


Stool studies — including culture, ova and parasite testing, and Clostridioides difficile toxin testing — are negative. CT of the abdomen and pelvis with oral contrast reveals pancolitis without perforation, strictures, fistula, or abscess formation.
A colonoscopy is performed (figure). Biopsies show mixed neutrophilic-lymphocytic infiltrates and are negative for cytomegalovirus, protozoal infections, and granulomas.
Supportive management is provided with intravenous fluids and antidiarrheal agents.
Which one of the following management strategies is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Stop ipilimumab temporarily, and start ciprofloxacin and metronidazole
Stop ipilimumab indefinitely, and start prednisone
Stop ipilimumab indefinitely, and start infliximab

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient has no indication for broad-spectrum antibiotics (e.g., ciprofloxacin and metronidazole), given that he is afebrile with a normal leukocyte count and a negative infectious workup.

B) CORRECT:

This patient is experiencing immunotherapy-induced colitis. Immunotherapy refers to a range of agents that promote an immune response against malignancies. These agents act by releasing the immune system from the mechanisms used by tumor cells to evade an immune response, such as tumor expression of a variety of molecules that modulate the immune response. Currently available classes of immunotherapy agents include cytotoxic T-lymphocyte antigen-4 (CTLA-4) inhibitors such as ipilimumab, programmed cell death receptor 1 (PD-1) inhibitors such as pembrolizumab, and programmed cell death ligand 1 (PD-L1) inhibitors such as atezolizumab and avelumab.

One of the main adverse effects of immunotherapy is that the release of immune system inhibition can lead to immunologically mediated inflammation and destruction of organs. The gastrointestinal system is frequently affected, usually in the form of colitis, which is more common with CTLA-4 inhibitors than with PD-1 inhibitors. Diarrhea, the most common symptom, usually starts within 6 weeks after treatment initiation and is usually nonbloody. Initial workup includes a thorough history and physical examination, comprehensive laboratory testing, infectious evaluation, and consideration of a CT scan and colonoscopy with biopsies. Colonic biopsies typically show a mixed neutrophilic-lymphocytic infiltrate.

The severity of diarrhea is graded according to the patient’s symptoms, and the grade then determines management.

• Grade 1: <4 episodes daily
• Grade 2: 4 to 6 episodes daily
• Grade 3: ≥7 episodes daily or requirement for inpatient hospitalization
• Grade 4: life-threatening consequences

For grade 1 disease, immunotherapy can usually be continued, and patients can be managed symptomatically.

For grade 2 disease, immunotherapy should be temporarily withheld until symptoms improve to grade 1, and glucocorticoids can be considered.

For grades 3 and 4 disease, the recommended approach is to permanently discontinue CTLA-4 inhibitors and start high-dose glucocorticoids (1–2 mg/kg/day). If the patient’s symptoms do not improve after 3 to 5 days of glucocorticoid therapy, tumor necrosis factor inhibitor therapy with infliximab should be considered. If the patient was taking a PD-1 or PD-L1 inhibitor (rather than a CTLA-4 inhibitor), that drug can be restarted after grade 3 symptoms improve to grade 1 — but should be permanently discontinued if grade 4 disease develops.

This patient has grade 3 disease (10 episodes of diarrhea daily) and should therefore stop the ipilimumab indefinitely and start high-dose glucocorticoids. He has no indication for broad-spectrum antibiotics (e.g., ciprofloxacin and metronidazole), given that he is afebrile with a normal leukocyte count and a negative infectious workup.

Key learning point: Management of grade 3 or 4 colitis induced by a cytotoxic T-lymphocyte antigen-4 (CTLA-4) inhibitor involves permanent discontinuation of the CTLA-4 inhibitor and treatment with high-dose glucocorticoids.

C) INCORRECT:

Colestipol has no role in the management of immunotherapy-induced colitis. It is used primarily for treating bile-acid-induced diarrhea.

D) INCORRECT:

For grade 1 immunotherapy-induced colitis, immunotherapy can usually be continued. However, this patient has grade 3 disease and should discontinue ipilimumab indefinitely.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient has grade 3 immunotherapy-induced colitis. Tumor necrosis factor inhibitor therapy with infliximab should be considered if the patient’s symptoms do not improve after 3 to 5 days of glucocorticoid therapy but infliximab is not a part of the initial treatment for grade 3 disease.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman reports 3 days of profound fatigue, making it difficult for her to get out of bed. She also reports feeling a bit dizzy when she stands up, and she has a slight retro-orbital headache.
Her medical history is significant for stage IIIB malignant melanoma, which was diagnosed 5 months ago after a biopsy of an irregular skin lesion revealed nodular melanoma with a depth of 2.2 mm, ulceration, and a high mitotic rate. Lymph-node dissection at the time revealed metastatic deposits in two lymph nodes, but there was no evidence of distant metastases on a CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis or an MRI of the head. Adjuvant ipilimumab was started 2 months ago.
The patient also has a history of reactive airways disease. She currently uses only an albuterol inhaler for this, although she did take three 7-day courses of prednisone during the past year (most recently 4 months ago) in the setting of upper respiratory infections. She currently has no respiratory symptoms.
Laboratory evaluation today shows a normal complete blood count and the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Sodium (mEq/liter)
132
136–145


Potassium (mEq/liter)
4.0
3.5–5.0


Fasting glucose (mg/dL)
75
70–100


Creatinine (mg/dL)
0.9
0.6–1.1


Thyroid-stimulating hormone (μU/mL)
0.8
0.5–4.7


Free thyroxine (ng/dL)
0.9
0.8–1.8


Adrenocorticotropic hormone (pg/mL)
9
10–60


Cortisol, 8 a.m. (μg/dL)
1.2
5.0–25.0


Which one of the following mechanisms is most likely causing this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: T cell-mediated destruction of the pituitary gland
Increase in the rate of hepatic hormone metabolism due to hepatic enzyme induction
Lymphocytic infiltration of the adrenal gland

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient is being treated with ipilimumab, an immune checkpoint inhibitor that has been shown to improve survival in patients with metastatic melanoma. Immune checkpoint inhibitors include cytotoxic T-lymphocyte antigen-4 (CTLA-4) inhibitors such as ipilimumab, programmed cell death receptor 1 (PD-1) inhibitors such as pembrolizumab, and programmed cell death ligand 1 (PD-L1) inhibitors such as avelumab. These agents are approved for treating a wide variety of cancers and are being studied in many more. However, their use has been associated with immune-related adverse events, often affecting the endocrine system. For example, CTLA-4 inhibitors commonly cause hypophysitis (autoimmune destruction of the pituitary gland), which can result in secondary adrenal insufficiency and other pituitary hormone deficiencies, whereas PD-1 and PD-L1 inhibitors more commonly cause thyroiditis. All subclasses of immune checkpoint inhibitors have been associated with type 1 diabetes and primary adrenal insufficiency. The average onset of endocrine complications with these medications appears to be 6 to 12 weeks after initiation of therapy.

This patient’s symptoms of fatigue and dizziness raise concern for adrenal insufficiency, and her laboratory results support this diagnosis, as her morning cortisol level is very low. In addition, her adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) level is inappropriately low given her low cortisol level. This localizes the cause of the adrenal insufficiency to the pituitary gland, making hypophysitis the most likely diagnosis. In addition, her low-normal thyroid-stimulating hormone level with low-normal free thyroxine level raises the possibility of central hypothyroidism, although the laboratory findings are not themselves diagnostic.

This patient should be treated with glucocorticoids and undergo additional blood testing to assess the remainder of her pituitary function. She should also undergo an MRI of the brain (with pituitary protocol) to assess for hypophysitis and rule out metastatic disease. Although hypophysitis is more likely, metastatic disease to the pituitary gland could also cause this clinical presentation; even though the patient had no evidence of disease on her recent brain MRI, pituitary lesions can sometimes be missed on brain MRI without fine cuts though the pituitary gland.

Key learning point: Endocrine complications of immune checkpoint inhibitors include adrenal insufficiency, thyroid disease, and hypophysitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Although many drugs, such as carbamazepine and rifampin, can induce hepatic enzymes and potentially lead to a need for dose adjustment of the hormone replacement, this is unlikely in this case. The patient is not taking any drugs that are known to increase hormone metabolism to an appreciable degree, and even if she was, her endogenous feedback system should simply stimulate additional hormone production and secretion to balance the increased requirements.

C) INCORRECT:

Adrenalitis (destruction of the adrenal gland from inflammation, usually characterized by lymphocytic infiltration of the adrenal gland) would be associated with an elevated (not low) ACTH level due to the loss of negative feedback from cortisol on pituitary ACTH production.

D) INCORRECT:

The patient is not exhibiting symptoms of an encephalitis (e.g., altered mental status); therefore, paraneoplastic brain inflammation is unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Exogenous glucocorticoid treatment could lead to the same laboratory findings seen in this patient. This could occur in the setting of acute negative feedback on ACTH production from a glucocorticoid that is not measured by the cortisol assay (such as dexamethasone or triamcinolone). Alternatively, it could occur from delayed recovery of ACTH production after cessation of treatment with any glucocorticoid (especially if the dose and duration were sufficient to cause cushingoid changes), in which case it could also be associated with the symptoms of adrenal insufficiency that were observed in this patient. However, the total amount of exogenous glucocorticoids received by this patient would not typically cause this degree of negative feedback, especially 4 months after her last course of therapy. It should be noted that glucocorticoids are usually avoided with immunotherapy because of concern that they could attenuate the immune checkpoint inhibitor-induced antitumor response.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old woman presents to the clinic for follow-up with continued hand and wrist pain, morning stiffness lasting more than 2 hours, and difficulty performing daily activities. She was diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis a year ago and started on methotrexate eight months ago at an appropriate dose. Despite strict medication adherence, she exhibits persistent joint swelling on examination. She denies any symptoms suggestive of pulmonary disease (see lab results and report).


Test
Result
Normal Values



C-reactive peptide
38 mg/L
< 8.2 mg/L


ESR
55 mm/h
3 - 15 mm/h


Rheumatoid factor
120 kIU/L
<58 kIU/L



Chest X-ray: Normal
Which of the following interventions is most appropriate to optimize disease control?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hydroxychloroquine is typically used for milder rheumatoid arthritis or as part of combination therapy. Switching from methotrexate to hydroxychloroquine in moderate to severe disease activity would represent a transition to a less potent agent, which is inappropriate given the patient's persistent high disease activity and lack of methotrexate contraindications.

B) CORRECT:

Adalimumab, a tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α) inhibitor, targets a key cytokine in the inflammatory cascade of rheumatoid arthritis. In cases where rheumatoid arthritis remains active despite methotrexate therapy, adding a biologic disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD) like adalimumab is recommended. Adalimumab reduces synovial inflammation and joint damage by binding to TNF-α, leading to improvements in inflammatory markers such as C-reactive protein and erythrocyte sedimentation rate. Its subcutaneous administration offers convenient dosing and effective long-term management for patients with persistent disease activity.

Key learning point: In patients with rheumatoid arthritis who have an inadequate response to methotrexate, adding a TNF inhibitor like adalimumab is an appropriate strategy to control disease activity and prevent joint damage.

C) INCORRECT:

Methotrexate has a ceiling effect, where increasing the dose provides minimal additional benefit and increases the risk of adverse effects like hepatotoxicity and marrow suppression. The patient's persistent joint swelling and elevated inflammatory markers suggest active disease despite an optimized methotrexate dose, indicating the need for an alternative or adjunctive therapeutic strategy.

D) INCORRECT:

While leflunomide is an effective DMARD, adding it to methotrexate raises concerns about cumulative hepatotoxicity. The patient's persistent active disease suggests the need for a therapy modification that avoids overlapping toxicities. Evidence-based strategies favor alternative agents or established combinations with better safety profiles.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to your clinic for follow-up. Two months ago, she underwent left renal transplantation for recurrent glomerulonephritis. At discharge, her creatinine was 80 μmol/L (49–93). She reports feeling well. Her current medications are tacrolimus and azathioprine. Her pulse is 85/min and blood pressure is 135/75 mm Hg. On examination, she has a well-healed surgical scar on her left lower abdomen. The remainder of the examination is normal. Which one of the following adverse effects of her medications should you monitor for?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hirsutism is a side effect of cyclosporine, which is not part of this patient's therapy. Hirsutism is not an adverse effect of tacrolimus or azathioprine. Tacrolimus is known to cause hair loss.

B) INCORRECT:

Polycythemia is a very rare side effect of azathioprine and tacrolimus. More commonly, azathioprine causes anemia and other cytopenias (leukopenia, thrombocytopenia) through bone marrow suppression. In rare cases, tacrolimus may also lead to bone marrow suppression.

C) CORRECT:

Calcineurin inhibitors such as tacrolimus, which are used to prevent acute transplant rejection, have nephrotoxic properties and may result in various degrees of kidney dysfunction, ranging from reversible acute kidney injury to chronic progressive renal disease and allograft dysfunction. Therefore, all transplant recipients who are taking calcineurin inhibitors require regular monitoring of the blood concentration of the drugs, and may also require dose reductions.

Other significant side effects of calcineurin inhibitors include hypertension, neurotoxicity, and metabolic abnormalities (e.g., glucose intolerance, hyperkalemia).

Key learning point: Calcineurin inhibitors like tacrolimus are nephrotoxic and require regular monitoring for kidney injury in transplant recipients.

D) INCORRECT:

Although mild hepatotoxicity and transaminitis may occur with azathioprine, the drug is unlikely to cause hepatic necrosis. Hepatotoxicity is not commonly associated with tacrolimus.

E) INCORRECT:

Gingival hyperplasia is a side effect of cyclosporine, which is not part of this patient's therapy. Although some individuals taking tacrolimus may develop gingival hyperplasia, a different side effect is much more common in these patients.

Azathioprine use is not associated with gingival hyperplasia.
questions.hint: Tacrolimus is a calcineurin inhibitor with similar side effects to cyclosporine.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with Crohn disease presents to the emergency department with a 1-week history of progressive fatigue, fever, and easy bruising. She has been taking azathioprine for the past 6 months. Physical examination reveals pallor, scattered petechiae on her arms and legs, and mild splenomegaly. Laboratory studies show hemoglobin 7.8 g/dL, white blood cell count 2,200/μL, and platelet count 45,000/μL. What is the most likely cause of her presentation?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – Azathioprine commonly causes pancytopenia through bone marrow suppression, which manifests as decreased production of all blood cell lines.

B) INCORRECT:

While Crohn disease can cause anemia from chronic inflammation or bleeding, it would not typically cause the severe leukopenia and thrombocytopenia seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Viral infections can cause cytopenias, but typically would not cause such severe pancytopenia affecting all cell lines to this degree.

D) INCORRECT:

Gastrointestinal bleeding could explain anemia but would not account for the severe leukopenia and thrombocytopenia. 

E) INCORRECT:

Nutritional deficiencies can cause anemia but rarely cause such severe pancytopenia with marked leukopenia and thrombocytopenia.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with a history of kidney transplant 8 months ago presents with a 2-week history of progressive dyspnea on exertion and dry cough. He adheres to his immunosuppressive regimen of tacrolimus, mycophenolate mofetil, and prednisone. Vital signs are BP, 120/80; P, 110; R, 24; T, 37.8°C (100.0°F); oxygen saturation, 90% on room air. Chest CT shows diffuse ground-glass opacities bilaterally without pleural effusions. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Refer for bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage
Begin empiric antifungal therapy with voriconazole

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage can provide a definitive diagnosis, it is not the most appropriate next step. Treatment for this disease may be initiated before diagnostic confirmation.

B) INCORRECT:

Broad-spectrum antibiotics are appropriate for bacterial pneumonia, but this patient's clinical presentation suggests a different disease.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- Progressive dyspnea and dry cough over 2 weeks in a patient who received a solid organ transplant and bilateral ground-glass opacities on chest CT suggest Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia. Trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole is the first-line treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Azithromycin is appropriate for atypical bacterial pneumonia, but this patient's clinical presentation suggests a different disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Voriconazole treats invasive aspergillosis and other fungal infections but is not appropriate for this patient's disease.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with rheumatoid arthritis presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of severe oral ulcers, abdominal pain, and diarrhea. They report accidentally taking their weekly methotrexate dose daily for the past week instead of once weekly. Laboratory results show leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated creatinine. What is the most appropriate initial pharmacological treatment to counteract this drug toxicity?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Methylprednisolone is a glucocorticoid that may be used in various emergency conditions and as an immunosuppressant, but it does not counteract methotrexate toxicity.

B) INCORRECT:

Cyanocobalamin treats vitamin B12 deficiency but has no role in methotrexate toxicity.

C) INCORRECT:

N-acetylcysteine is used as an antidote for acetaminophen toxicity by replenishing glutathione stores. It has no mechanism of action against methotrexate toxicity, which involves folate pathway inhibition rather than glutathione depletion.

D) INCORRECT:

Activated charcoal is only effective for recent ingestions and works by binding drugs in the gastrointestinal tract. Given the patient took multiple doses over a week, the drug has already been absorbed and distributed, making decontamination ineffective

E) CORRECT:

Correct – Leucovorin (folinic acid) is the appropriate treatment for methotrexate intoxication. Leucovorin is an active derivative of folic acid that bypasses the blocked folate pathway by providing reduced folate directly to cells.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents to the emergency department with a 4-week history of intermittent fever, night sweats, and productive cough with occasional blood-streaked sputum. The patient has been treated with adalimumab for rheumatoid arthritis for the past 2 years with good disease control. Vital signs show BP, 125/82; P 92, T, 38.9°C (102°F), and oxygen saturation 94% on room air. Physical examination reveals decreased breath sounds and dullness to percussion in the right upper lobe. Chest imaging demonstrates a right upper lobe consolidation with central cavitation. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Discharge home with antibiotics for CAP
Order CT angiography to evaluate for pulmonary embolism
Administer high-dose corticosteroids for drug-induced pneumonitis
Obtain blood cultures and start empiric antifungal therapy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Discharge with oral antibiotics would be inappropriate for a patient with cavitary lung disease on TNF-alpha inhibitor therapy.

B) INCORRECT:

The clinical presentation and imaging findings are not consistent with pulmonary embolism. The patient has a subacute febrile illness with productive cough and cavitary consolidation, which points toward an infectious etiology rather than thromboembolic disease.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – TNF-alpha inhibitors like adalimumab significantly increase the risk of tuberculosis reactivation.

D) INCORRECT:

Drug-induced pneumonitis from TNF-alpha inhibitors typically presents as bilateral interstitial disease rather than unilateral cavitary consolidation. Additionally, corticosteroids would be contraindicated if tuberculosis is suspected, as they could worsen mycobacterial infections.

E) INCORRECT:

While immunocompromised patients can develop fungal infections, the clinical presentation with upper lobe cavitation is more characteristic of tuberculosis reactivation. Blood cultures alone would not provide rapid diagnosis, and antifungal therapy would not address the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 4-week history of fatigue, low-grade fever, and persistent cough. She has rheumatoid arthritis and was started on infliximab 6 months ago. She reports unintentional weight loss of 8 pounds over the past month. Vital signs show temperature 38.2°C, and chest examination reveals decreased breath sounds in the right upper lung field. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pneumocystis pneumonia typically occurs in patients with severe immunodeficiency like advanced HIV and generally would not feature focal unilateral lung findings on examination.

B) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid arthritis typically affects joints and would not explain the pulmonary symptoms, fever, and weight loss pattern described in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

While immunosuppressed patients are at risk for fungal infections, the specific combination of constitutional symptoms and pulmonary findings in a patient on TNF-α inhibitor therapy makes an alternative diagnosis more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Community-acquired pneumonia typically presents more acutely and would be less likely to cause the gradual onset of constitutional symptoms and significant weight loss seen in this case.

E) CORRECT:

Correct – TNF-α inhibitors like infliximab significantly increase the risk of tuberculosis reactivation. The subacute presentation with constitutional symptoms, weight loss, and pulmonary involvement in a patient on biologic immunosuppression should raise strong suspicion for TB reactivation.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman comes to the rheumatology clinic for management of severe joint pain and morning stiffness affecting her hands and knees for the past 8 months. She was diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis 2 years ago and has not responded adequately to methotrexate and hydroxychloroquine. She has no history of recent travel or exposure to sick contacts. Past medical history is remarkable for hypertension well controlled with lisinopril. She does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. She visits her primary care physician regularly and is up-to-date on age-appropriate screenings. Temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 82/min, and blood pressure is 124/74 mm Hg. Physical examination shows swelling and tenderness of the metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints bilaterally. Laboratory studies, including a complete blood count and liver function tests, are within normal limits. The physician is considering starting a tumor necrosis factor alpha (TNF-α) inhibitor. In addition to screening for latent tuberculosis infection, which of the following is the most appropriate screening test for this patient?

choices.text: Hepatitis B and hepatitis C serologies

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Current rheumatology guidelines recommend hepatitis B serology as well as hepatitis C antibody testing before starting biologic disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs, such as TNF-α inhibitors. Screening for chronic viral hepatitis prior to initiation of TNF-α inhibitor therapy is essential because these agents can reactivate hepatitis B and, less commonly, hepatitis C. Immunosuppression with TNF-α inhibitors can allow unchecked viral replication, which may lead to fulminant hepatic failure in patients with occult or chronic hepatitis B infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Echocardiography may be required prior to TNF-α inhibitor therapy in patients with features of heart failure, because these agents are contraindicated in moderate to severe heart failure (NYHA class III/IV). This patient has no features or history of heart disease, so echocardiography is not indicated.

C) INCORRECT:

Colonoscopy is not indicated prior to TNF-α inhibitor therapy unless there is a specific indication such as colorectal cancer screening (based on age and/or family history), gastrointestinal symptoms, or inflammatory bowel disease. This patient has no gastrointestinal symptoms or personal or family history of colon cancer, and she is up to date on age-appropriate screenings, which include a colonoscopy every 10 years, starting at 45 years of age.

D) INCORRECT:

While immunosuppressive therapies can accelerate disease progression in patients with uncontrolled HIV, guidelines primarily emphasize screening for different infections, which are more commonly reactivated by TNF-α inhibitors. HIV testing may be appropriate if there are specific risk factors (e.g., intravenous drug use or high-risk sexual behaviors) or symptoms that suggest HIV infection, but it is not routinely mandated for all patients starting TNF-α inhibitors.

E) INCORRECT:

Chronic inflammation in rheumatoid arthritis can cause AA amyloidosis, which typically affects the kidneys and can cause nephrotic syndrome or progressive renal insufficiency. However, this patient presents with no signs of renal involvement. Urinalysis is only required prior to initiating TNF-α inhibitor therapy in patients with rheumatoid arthritis who have urinary symptoms or clinical features of renal involvement.
questions.hint: TNF-α plays a role in viral containment.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. Three months ago, she underwent heart transplantation for restrictive cardiomyopathy and was started on transplant rejection prophylaxis. Her pulse is 76/min and blood pressure is 148/82 mm Hg. Physical examination shows enlargement of the gum tissue. There is a well-healed scar on her chest. Serum studies show hyperlipidemia. The physician recommends removing a drug that decreases T cell activation by inhibiting the transcription of interleukin-2 from the patient's treatment regimen and replacing it with a different medication. Which of the following drugs is the most likely cause of the adverse effects seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sirolimus is an immunosuppressant drug that can be used for transplant rejection prophylaxis. It binds FK binding protein (FKBP) to form a complex that inhibits mTOR. This inhibition prevents activation of mTOR kinase, which leads to inhibition of interleukin-2 (IL-2) induced T cell proliferation and impaired B cell differentiation. Sirolimus does not inhibit the transcription of IL-2. Side effects of this drug include hypertension and hyperlipidemia, as seen in this patient. However, it is not known to cause gingival hyperplasia. Further important adverse effects of sirolimus include infection, malignancy, pancytopenia, and insulin resistance.

They exert their immunosuppressant effect via various mechanisms of action, including inhibition of NF-κB, suppression of T cell proliferation, and induction of apoptosis in lymphocytes. Cyclosporine is an immunosuppressant drug that is commonly used for transplant rejection prophylaxis. It binds cyclophilin to form a complex that inhibits calcineurin. Cyclosporine is the only calcineurin inhibitor to cause gingival hyperplasia, so it is most likely the drug that was used in this patient.

Further important side effects of cyclosporine include increased susceptibility to infection and increased risk for malignancy.
Image Description:

Mycophenolate mofetil (MMF) acts by inhibiting inosine monophosphate dehydrogenase (IMPDH), resulting in selective inhibition of lymphocyte proliferation.

Azathioprine (AZA) is a purine analog that is converted, first, to 6-mercaptopurine and, then, into thioinosine monophosphate (TIM), a cytotoxic agent, which acts to block nucleotide synthesis and inhibit lymphocyte proliferation.

Methotrexate (MTX) is a folic acid antagonist (antimetabolite), which acts primarily by inhibiting the clonal expansion of B and T cells.

Cyclophosphamide causes alkylation of DNA/RNA, resulting in impaired DNA cross-linking and DNA synthesis.

Basiliximab/daclizumab inhibits the alpha chain (CD25 antigen) of the IL-2 receptor of T cells, resulting in a reduction of T-cell responses and the expansion of natural killer cells.

Sirolimus/everolimus inhibits mTOR kinase resulting in the inhibition of the IL-2-mediated cell cycle. This leads to reduced T-cell activation and B-cell differentiation, resulting in decreased IgM, IgG, and IgA production.

Tacrolimus (FK 506) and pimecrolimus bind to the FK506 binding protein (FKBP) resulting in inhibition of calcineurin, an enzyme necessary for the activation of NFAT. This leads to reduced gene transcription and activation of T cells. Cyclosporine A binds cyclophilin, which also inhibits calcineurin.

Glucocorticoids (corticosteroids) directly inhibit intracellular NF-κB, a protein complex responsible for transcription of DNA, cytokine production, and cell survival.

E) INCORRECT:

Azathioprine is an immunosuppressant drug that can be used for transplant rejection prophylaxis. Azathioprine is a precursor of 6-mercaptopurine, an antimetabolite that blocks purine synthesis and subsequently inhibits the proliferation of lymphocytes. It does not inhibit the transcription of interleukin-2. Important adverse effects of azathioprine include bone marrow suppression (leading to pancytopenia), hepatotoxicity, acute pancreatitis, infection, malignancy, and fetal harm in pregnant women. Azathioprine is not known to cause any of the adverse effects observed in this patient.

Further important adverse effects of mycophenolate mofetil include first-trimester pregnancy loss and congenital malformations, infection, malignancy, neutropenia, and hyperglycemia.
